A man wishes to cross the river with a wolf, a goat and some hay (don't ask me why!) He has a small boat, but unfortunately, he can only take one thing across at a time. What is worse, if he leaves the wolf and the goat alone together, the wolf will eat the goat, and if he leaves the goat with the hay, the goat will eat the hay. How does he do it?

Act like a student who should write his thought process in high detail.

The man first takes the goat across the river. He then leaves the goat on the other side of the river and returns with the hay. He then takes the wolf across the river, leaving the hay on the other side of the river. He then returns to the first side of the river with the goat. Finally, he takes the goat across the river, leaving the wolf on the first side of the river.

Here is a more detailed explanation of the man's thought process:

The man knows that he cannot leave the wolf and the goat alone together, or the wolf will eat the goat. He also knows that he cannot leave the goat with the hay, or the goat will eat the hay. Therefore, he must find a way to transport the wolf, the goat, and the hay across the river without leaving any of them alone with the others.

The man's first step is to take the goat across the river. He knows that the wolf will not eat the goat if he is not there, so he can leave the wolf on the first side of the river. Once the goat is on the other side of the river, the man returns to the first side of the river with the hay. He then takes the wolf across the river, leaving the hay on the other side of the river. This time, the man can leave the goat on the first side of the river, because the wolf is not there to eat it. Finally, the man returns to the first side of the river with the goat and takes it across the river, leaving the wolf on the first side of the river. This way, the man has transported all three items across the river without leaving any of them alone with the others.

The man's solution is clever and efficient. It requires him to make three trips across the river, but it ensures that the wolf, the goat, and the hay are all transported safely.

2. He leaves the goat on the other side of the river and returns with the hay.
3. He takes the wolf across the river, leaving the hay on the other side of the river.
4. He returns to the first side of the river with the goat.
5. Finally, he takes the goat across the river, leaving the wolf on the first side of the river.
